text: Take that away, and their campaign time and effort will be spent relative to the community’s size. (7/7)
author: smotus

text: The EC gives an incentive for candidates to spend disproportionate time in smaller, more competitive states. (6/7)
author: smotus

text: Hey, look, CO Gov candidate Jared Polis campaigned in small towns in the final weeks before the 2018 election. https://www.coloradodems.org/colorado-democratic-party-announces-first-leg-of-colorado-for-all-bus-tour/ … (5/7)
author: smotus

text: Yes, most of Obama’s offices were in the Front Range cities (where most people live), but not nearly all. Quite a few were in small mountain communities. (4/7)
author: smotus

text: In my paper with @johnmsides & @vavreck, we looked at presidential campaign field office locations in 2012. Here’s Colorado. https://www.tandfonline.com/doi/abs/10.1080/10584609.2015.1029657 …  (3/7)
author: smotus

text: The thing is, we don’t have to guess how candidates will behave without an EC. We have statewide elections all the time, and those are simply decided by popular vote. Do the campaigns occur just in major cities? No. (2/7)
author: smotus

text: Would abolishing the Electoral College mean that candidates will only campaign in a handful of urban areas? No. [Thread] 1/7
